text:
This was a very easy to follow, and delicious recipe.  I prepared it for a pot-luck at work, and it was a hit.  Very nice lemon flavor, and good texture to filling.  For the meringue I used powdered sugar instead of granulated sugar......gives it a nice sheen, and it doesn't sweat too much when it's in the fridge and also the peaks seem to brown nicer...oh, and I also added a couple drops of vanilla to meringue....(it's a habit).  Overall.........KUDO'S FOR THIS PIE!!!

text:
Pretty good as lemon meringue pies go - it thickened nicely, but I had trouble with the meringue pulling away from the side of the pan. If you like a somewhat tart pie, you may want to substitute about 1/3 c. of the water with lemon juice. Just don't do more than that (as I did) or you'll really pucker tongues. Add 1/2 tsp. cream of tartar and 1 tsp. vanilla to the meringue.

country:
None
text:
This pie was delicious! I followed the advice of some of the others. I made the meringue first and added 1/2 tsp. of cream of tartar and 1/2 tsp. vanilla extract. For the filling I replaced the water with milk and added another 1/4 cup of sugar. I strained the filling before pouring it into the crust. For the crust I used Nick Malgieri's recipe for sweet pie dough, which included ingredients such as butter, baking powder and one egg. The pie was delicious with great flavor, smooth texture, and the meringue was perfect.  I will definitely make it again, but the next time I will not add the additional 1/4 cup of sugar.

text:
This came out perfectly. I followed the suggestions of others by using milk instead of water,adding cream of tartar to the meringue, and using 1/4 of fresh lemon juice. It was not to tart according to different family members. I cooked the lemon custard until it was very thick, thicker than pudding would look. I did get the moisture droplets on the meringue once I refridgerated it. I think next time I'll wait until it completely cools until I put it in the fridge. Also the meringue did shrink afterwards. I was given the suggestion of adding some melted marshmallow cream to the meringue. I may try it. All in all a delicious recipe!

text:
A crucial piece of information is missing from the directions which is why some people may have found the pie to be extremely runny or thought it turned out disasterously.  The first time I made it the pie was extremely runny and by a fluke I discovered the reason.  You must REFRIDGERATE the pie overnight or for several hours so that it actually firms up.  I hope this helps.

WUNDERBAR!!!!!I consider myself a pretty cook cook-but there are two items I fail at EVERY time.  Pancakes and Lemon Meringue Pie.  I get the Meringue Part right-its the Filling that gets me.  This was my fourth try at my husband's favorite dessert.  First time I made it with Jello Pie Filling-it worked but nothing to write home about.  We will not discuss the second or third try. I used milk instead of water and I used 1/2 lemon juice and three lemons.  Perfect.  My only problem was-what I was supposed to do when I took it out of the oven.  After searching All recipes for about one half hour-I came across something similar to this pie-which instructed to leave away from draft.  No time-so I just put it on counter for 1 1/2 hours and then in the fridge for another hour.  It was slightly warm still-but OH MY GOODNESS-Heaven.  Now I am in search of the perfect pie crust....

None
text:
I've tried this pie twice now, and it's still just okay. The first time, I followed the recipe to the letter, and while the pie was fine, it wasn't tart enough for me -- in fact, there wasn't much lemon flavour at all. The second time, I added the juice and zest from three lemons instead of two, which should have worked just fine, but I also made the mistake of substituting milk for the water, a suggestion made by other reviewers. I will never, ever add milk to a lemon meringue pie again. It ruined the consistency for me entirely. 
In all, this pie was easy to make, and if that's what you're looking for in a lemon meringue pie, this is the one for you. Personally, I'd rather put in the extra effort for a really smashing pie.

text:
Great recipe!!  Everyone says it's the best they've ever tasted.  It is a little more time consuming than just opening a lemon pudding box, but well worth it!  I did change a few things, just to fit my liking.  I used milk instead of water for a creamier filling.  Also, when filling was cooking, I tasted it and added more sugar or lemon juice depending on the taste I was looking for.  Some people like it more tart than others.  Also, I added 1 tsp. of lemon juice to the meringue mix, just for a little added touch.  All in all, it is a great recipe.  Highly recommend it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I’ve made this twice.  For what it’s worth I’m a guy who doesn’t have a lot of experience in the kitchen but am getting better.  First time I made this I’d give it a 6 due to my ability.  Second time I made it, I did whole thing start to finish in about 30 mins and it was great!

Advice: (1) I have a lemon tree.  I used 1/4 cup juice.  Next time I will probably add 3 tablespoons more.  (2). Meringue :  don’t wisk, use beaters.  Whip it up FIRST and THEN put your lemon filling on the stove.  (3) when done pour boiling hot filling into pie crust, then Immediately place meringue on top.  That is key to get it to stick together.  (4) after baking, cool on rack for 10 mins and then into fridge for 90 mins UNCOVERED.   What you do after that is up to you.

I CHANGED ABSOLUTELY NOTHING ABOUT THIS RECIPE as it frustrates me when people change things then rate it. I believe you must try the original recipe first in order to know what (if anything) you should change. Having never made a lemon meringue pie before in my life, I don’t understand why people were struggling with this pie. The lemon filling set up nicely and had a great lemon flavor and the meringue was a sweet marshmallowy flavor/texture. I do not feel any changes were necessary and would make this recipe again! photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3158466.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie for me needed some help:
The submitter assumes the reader knows how to prebake a crust for a lemon meringue pie, it should be stated in the recipe, I blind baked mine for 10 mintes at 400 degrees 
I felt there was not enough thickener, I omitted the flour and doubled the cornstarch, I do not like the floury taste it can impart when the pie is not baked
For me not enough lemon, I would double it, using 4 tbsps of zest and 1/2 cup lemon juice, reduce water to 1 1/4 cups. I also added a few drops of yellow food colour as it was not very yellow
For the meringue I always add 1/2 tsp cream of tartar to help stabilize the peaks
Do not cover your lemon meringue pie it will get soggy and weepy.

userID:
21820746
Display Name:
Ruth
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good pie, though the recipe needs some clarification.  Following some of the tips posted by other reviewers, I prepared the meringue first and set it aside, before preparing the lemon curd.  I juiced 3 lemons to get 1/2 cup of juice.  After adding the tempered eggs to the lemon curd, I continued to stir and boil for about 2 minutes.  The curd was still somewhat runny.  I poured the lemon curd into the baked pie crust, and immediately topped the piping hot mixture with the meringue, and put it straight into the oven for baking.  When I took the pie out of the oven, it was still visibly jiggly, and I was very worried that it wouldn't set.  I allowed it to fully cool to room temperature, then wrapped it in foil and put it into the fridge overnight.  When I served it the next day, it was perfectly set, and the meringue stayed put without separating and sliding off.  It sliced perfectly and made a lovely and delicious pie.  The pie is definitely NOT ready in 40 minutes, as you have to allow plenty of time for refrigeration to allow the pie filling to set.  The only change I made was that I forgot to zest the fresh lemons, so I substituted a sprinkle of dried lemon peel (about 1/8 tsp) in the filling.  (P.S. I don't recommend the video, as the video incorrectly instructs you to spoon the dry cornstarch into the liquid in the pan.)

text:
Follow the recipe exactly, and it will turn out fine, even for a meringue novice like me. Just make sure you have the meringue ready to go as soon as the pudding-like filling is ready, so that it can be put directly on very hot filling taken straight from the stove. 

After baking, I let it rest on the counter for about 2 hours and then refrigerated it uncovered overnight. Luscious, smooth, lemony and a beautiful color that caused my husband to ask if I used food coloring! (Nope!)

I wasn't sure exactly how much lemon to actually use since that can vary depending on the size of the lemons, but mine made about 1/2 cup and that was just right for us.   We had half a bottle of wine which we drank with our pie and it made a perfect ending to a beautiful Spring day.

text:
I've made this pie approximately 10 times now and all but this last time it was superb. I made the mistake of modifying the recipe. I ask myself if this pie could get any better but decided to try  the "tweaks" that CARTHECOOK suggested. It's a whole different pie. Lemon juice is not a substitute for fresh squeezed lemons and not using the lemon zest causes it to lose that slight tartness that makes lemon pies so dang good. The extra corn starch makes the filling too stiff and the sugar changed nothing.  
Each to there own but the "tweaks" makes a 5 star pie a 3. Just wish I would have decided not to make the changes when taking dessert for friends that request lemon pie every time we come. Th ONLY change I would make to this recipe is oven temp for the meringue. At 350 it takes 20 minutes+.

city:

country:
None
text:
This was my first time making lemon meringue pie.  Lemon part turned out AWESOME.  I had some difficulties making the meringue (tried three times) and on the last try looked for another meringue recipe and found this one:

3 egg whites 
1/4 tsp. cream of tartar 
6 tbsp. sugar 
1/2 tsp. vanilla 
Beat the egg whites and cream of tartar until soft peaks form . Add sugar 1 tbsp. at a time , beating constantly until sugar is dissolved and whites are glossy . Beat in vanilla . 

After making the meringue with this recipe, the pie turned out GREAT!

text:
Best lemon meringue pie recipe I've found to date! The only thing I'd like to add is in regards to this recipe claiming that it's ready in 40 mins, which is impossible unless you want a sloppy mess. You should cool the filling a bit before putting the meringue on it (I put it in the fridge until it goes from hot to warm) and after it's done baking you should let it cool at least 30-60 min before serving it.

city:

None
text:
My 1st time making lemon meringue and it worked!  I read a lot of reviews and here's what worked for me.  I followed the recipe exactly as stated.  2 important things - cook your pie shell first and increase the number of hours this really takes to about 8 hours.  I had time for it to cool  but not chill and it wasn't quite as great.  Luckily, I made 2 pies and the next day served the other chilled one  - incredible!  Also, definitely double the recipe for the filling.  It was great, can't imagine how little there would be if I hadn't doubled it.  I kept meringue portion the same and it was enough for me but not a gigantic portion.  I didn't know how to do meringue so here's what I learned.  Whisk the eggs until foamy also means - until it doubles or triples in size so go beyond just the foamy part.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this, my first ever homemade lemon meringue pie, yesterday for easter dinner and it was a hit.  I read lots of the reviews and made the meringue first, so that I could put it immediately on the hot lemon filling. I also followed others' advice to use about 1/2 cup of lemon juice (about 2.5 lemons), and the zest from only one lemon.  The tart/sweet balance was perfect.  The only other change I made was to add 1/4 tsp of cream of tartar to the meringue as it really helps stiffen and preserve the peaks in the meringue, making for a beautiful effect on the finished product.  My only advice to others is to make sure you CONSTANTLY whisk the lemon mixture as you are cooking it or you'll have some lumps.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe! I made this twice now. The first time, I was in the middle of the process when I realized I couldn't find my measuring spoons. So, I ended up not quite putting the right amount of corn starch in. Needless to say, it was a little runny that time. Second time around, equipped with proper measuring spoons, it turned out perfect.  After reading some of the reviews where people had trouble, I will say: if your pie is runny, its because you didn't add enough starch .. the second time around I did add an extra 1/4 teaspoon of cornstarch). If the meringue isn't fluffing up enough, I used a hand mixer and it fluffed up perfect with stiff peaks (this was my first pie I ever made, and first time making meringue).

userID:
7084192
Display Name:
Jennifer Sarmento Dussault
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2771393.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made mine gluten free!!  Instead of flour I substituted equal amount of Trader Joe's gluten free flour mix.  I used these modifications from CARTHECOOK 's suggestions in her review:
Filling:  1-1/4c sugar (regular granules), 3-1/2 TBSP corn starch
Meringue: mixed for about 2 minutes then added 1/2 tsp cream of tartar & 1 tsp vanilla extract.  I let it beat for the amount of time it took me to wash a few dishes - maybe 3 minutes or so.  It came out stiff and fluffy. 
 The filling was super thick before even adding the egg yolks.  The pies are in the fridge now, but I don't doubt they will be perfect!  A little hint:  Use farm fresh eggs for increased color and flavor!

None
text:
My first attempt at lemon meringue. I read the review from CARTHECOOK, and skipped the zest.  Like some of the other reviewers I increased the lemons to three.  I made Emeril's Basic Pie Crust and baked two crusts for about 15 minutes.  I doubled the recipe but whisked in more than 1/2 cup ( 1 cup doubled) of the hot sugar mixture.  I put the meringue on top of the custard while it was still warm.  I cooled the pie on the counter over an hour, but got over zealous and cut into one of the pies, before it was chilled.  It was delicious but began to ooze.  I then placed both pies into the refrig uncovered, after watching the related video, for the recommended three hours..

text:
First off, the flavor in this pie was INCREDIBLE! I loved the fresh lemon flavor and the creamy meringue (though my little siblings did not care for it as much :P) However, the consistency of the lemon part reminded me a bit of creamy jell-o, and had a bit of a slippery texture. This may have to do with the fact that I used arrowroot starch (what we had on hand) instead of the cornstarch... Perhaps this was the issue? But overall I liked this recipe enough to want to mess around with the ingredients to see if I can get the texture just right.

text:
I like to read the reviews before trying the recipe. The author who made this recipe is perfect for me. However, I was mislead by the reviewers abt using Meyer Lemons, these lemons are crossed between a manderin orange and a lemon, which I didn't know. I bought some from the store, mom says they look like oranges, somewhat, and then I read the package. They had a small taste/smell of an orange, I was skeptical and used less than 2 lemons and dilute it w/ lemon juice.  I would still use the Meyer Lemons, along w/ the lemon juice.  It is sweet tasting, but I still taste orange. I doubled the recipe and use 2 small aluminum foil pans (recycled) :D  Delicious recipe, tx for sharing

This is my first lemon pie and my first review here so I cannot do comparisons. This recipe is really easy to make. I also made the "Perfect Pie crust II" good combination. I suppose with ready made pie crust it would be a piece of cake. The filling is easy to make but next time I will use less lemon juice and eggs because it came out really sour. I also used a bit more cornstarch than recommended, the filling needed it. Overall lovely recipe but not excited, will try out more!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/666057.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW!!! This is incredibly easy and delicious. I followed the instructions, I just executed them a little different. How I did it was in the top of a double boiler I combined the sugar, flour, cornstarch, salt, water, lemon juice and zest, and the egg yolks. I whisked all of this together constantly over medium high heat. I timed it, and seven minutes later it was very creamy and thick. No need for tempering the egg yolks. I took it off the heat and stirred in the butter. Next time I won't be using the butter because I couldn't see a difference in the taste. Oh, and my double boiler was nothing fancy. I used a large stainless steel mixing bowl and set it over a pot of simmering water. I poured this mixture into a graham cracker crust, and since I don't care for meringue, when it had cooled in the refrigerator, I topped it with cool-whip. I will be making this very often for sure.

This turned out to be a great pie! It was my first too! The only thing I found a little unnecessary was the lemon zest. Some people prefer the lemon filling to be just lemon. Note: when you make the meringue be careful to clean your tools very carefully. I had some water in the bowl and on the whisk, so the meringue didn't form peaks. Sadly I had to dump it out, but the next one was much better.

text:
I L-O-V-E this recipe. I followed the directions exactly for the pie filling. However, I deviated from the meringue recipe by adding 1/2 cup sugar instead of 6 tablespoons and also added a teaspoon of vanilla extract.
I have had difficulty with meringue in the past so here are a few tips
1.) Make sure the egg whites are room temperature; it makes a big difference.
2.) Add the sugar gradually and not all at once. I gently shake the measuring cup sprinkling some into the mixing bowl then whisking it in completely before repeating the process.

text:
This is for a shallow pie crust. I have deep 9 in pie dish, when doubled filled up only half way. As for cooking until super thick, not necessary the curd will thicken when it cools. Using milk instead of water (as mentioned in the comments) in my opinion tones down the lemon a little, so does vanilla but makes it a tiny bit more creamy. I know because when I made the second batch I tried it with milk instead of water. I ended up combining the two batches to fill the pie dish more. Overall nice flavor and texture and ideal for a small pie.

text:
Very easy to make but runny when done.  Try refrigerating after cooling to firm up the filling.  My pies were gorgeous, but I was so disappointed when I attempted to serve slices.  I needed a spoon!  It was Lemon Meringue Soup.  :-(  Flavor however was outstanding.  I made one lemon and one key lime.  I will definately retry this pie - maybe play with the filling while cooking to thicken prior to refrigerating!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/923261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum. :) I actually chose this recipe because I was in the mood for something sweet, but didn't have a lot of ingredients at home and it was too late to go to the store. So, I had to improvise a little. First, I used a graham cracker crust. I had no fresh lemons, so I used a half cup of lemon juice. The only other alterations I made was to use 1 cup milk and 1/2 cup water, since the reviewers were divided on which was better. I used the proportions specified in the recipe for everything else and it came out great. Good ratio of meringue to custard. Ideally, it would have been more lemon-y, but that is a shortcoming provided by my lack of fresh lemons and zest, not due to any fault of the recipe. The custard was a bit thick and gummy for my liking, but it wasn't *bad,* per se. I will make this recipe again with a few tweaks. Thanks for sharing!

text:
I have made this recipe at least 5 times and it always, always turns out well!  In the very beginning, I had a little extra liquid and made two slight accommodations:  I sprinkled a little bit of corn starch in the bottom of the pre-cooked crust just before I poured in the lemon curd filling.  Also, I let the pie cool in the oven for about an hour.  Now it's perfect!  I can't tell you how many requests I get for this pie!  You absolutely can't go wrong!

text:
This was the first time I have ever made lemon meringue pie and it came out perfectly! I was quite proud. I feel that the recipe being simple was the key to my success. I followed the directions and took some of the suggestions in the reviews: Increased sugar to 1 1/4 cups, increase cornstarch to 3 1/2 TBSP, added 1 tsp vanilla to meringue.  I made this for Thanksgiving and my family is full of lemon meringue pie lovers, all of whom love love loved this pie! I love cooking but haven't had much experience with cooking up pie fillings like this, so if I can do it just by following this recipe, I imagine most anyone can. I used a store-bought crust, however. I haven't mastered the art of the pie crust, I'm afraid.

I have made this many times before, and I love this recipe.  It turns out great every time.  I wanted to make this today, but I do not care for regular pie crust, so I decided to change it up a little.  I made a graham cracker, coconut crust that I prebaked.  Then I added the filling, the meringue on top, and then sprinkled it with some more coconut before baking it.  Love it even more now.  The lemon coconut flavors work so well together.  The filling on this pie is so perfect that I think any crust would taste good.

Excellent recipe.  I used a store bought graham cracker crust.  I also really cooked the lemon filling fairly long to make sure it was thickened.  Make the meringue before you are ready to pour the lemon filling so that you add the meringue while filling is hot.  I add 1/2 teaspoon of cream of tartar to meringue (habit).  Best next day!

This tasted fantastic! It was very creamy and had just the right amount of tartness. I did manage to ruin the meringue topping though! After it finished baking, I took it out of the oven. It sat for about 5 minutes and I decided that it looked too wet, so I decided to bake it a little longer. The oven was pre-heating and I decided to put it back in WHILE IT WAS STILL HEATING! I started smelling a burned smell, I looked in the oven and the meringue was completely black! I just peeled the burned part off and baked it a little longer to make it look slightly presentable. It still tasted FANTASTIC, despite my numerous mistakes!

text:
I made this with artificial sweetener (I used "Ideal" sweetener) for my mother-in-law's birthday.  She's a diabetic & loves lemon meringue pie but hasn't been able to have it in years.  She was thrilled with it.  I did substitute milk for water & I don't know if it was because I used artificial sweetner, but I think the filling could have been fuller so next time I make it, I'll increase the filling by half again.  Anyway, the pies (I made 2) were a hit with everyone, even the non-diabetic folks.  They all said the flavor was wonderful, so I can only imagine how good this must taste with real sugar.  The only complaint is that these pies took FOREVER to make, but it could have been because I made my own pie crusts as well.  I'll be making this for my mother-in-law again as a treat for her for mother's day!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Made this with a few changes. I used milk instead of water. I upped the cornstarch as written and then added a teaspoon more. I had the baked crust waiting  in the oven and the meringue already waiting. for some reason, I had a cup and one half  of lemon juice real and bottled mixed. Dont know where I got that from.? the filling got thick when it boiled the first time, then I added the yolks and butter and by the time it quickly came back to a thick boil it was done. I put it in the hot crust, and immediately added the meringue. I baked about 20 minutes, to get the crust brown. Sat one hour on a rack and then chilled for 5 hours. It could of done with less  lemon Im sure, but it was really good. Stll passable even with all that lemon. It was an easy recipe and tasted very good, I had no runniness or liquid anywhere. the meringue stayed in tact and was thick and wonderful. Even with a professional kitchen Aid it does take a long time to get the stiff peaks. This one was a winner and will make it again. (with less lemon) lol!!

text:
ok, when I tried to make Lemon Meringue Pie as a teenager, it fell apart and my mother laughed at me. Devastating. 2 decades later, I thought I should address my fears. This recipe is great - if you are a pie novice take particular note of the bit about the pieshell being warm when you add the filling and the filling being warm when you add the meringue, and it is easy. Also follow the instructions about how long to cook the lemon curd. I debuted this at my husband's pie-loving family's Thanksgiving, and (whew!) it was a success. Next I will cook it for my mother...Thanks!

text:
wow, just incredible.  I made to very small changes as I had no fresh lemons and had to use lemon juice and some of my home dried lemon zest. this was just a great pie and so easy.  I used a grahm cracker crust and it added a little extra sweet crunch at the bottem. see changes below.    Ingredients  1 cup white sugar   2 tablespoons all-purpose flour   3 ½ tablespoons cornstarch   1/4 teaspoon salt   ¾ cup water/ ¾ milk  ½ cup lemon juice  ½ tsp lemon zest  2 tablespoons butter   4 egg yolks, beaten   1 (9 inch) pie crust, baked(best if you use a graham cracker crust)

country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe.  This is the first lemon meringue I have made and I was very pleased with the results.  I do wish I had read more reviews before making the pie.  I let the curd cool down too much before putting the meringue on top so not only did the meringue separate from the crust on one side but the pie was slightly watery.  Make sure you also cool the pie an hour after baking at room temp then put in the refrigerator for at least 3 hrs to ensure pie has set before cutting.  Also, my 2 lemons yelded about 6oz of lemon juice and it was perfect.  I only put about a teaspoon of zest in the pie.

INCREDIBLE!  Following the advice of others, I substituted milk for the water and I let the pie cool for 1 hour on the counter before refrigerating for at least 3 hours.  To make stiffer meringue, whip the eggs in a bowl that is suspended over simmering water, or that is partially submerged in simmering water.

miremba

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
UPDATE:  I baked this pie in the evening and served it the following night.  The crust had turned exceptionally soggy and was rather disgusting as a result.  The taste was still fantastic but soggy crust as a result of the filling isn't a good thing.  The merangue had also started separating from the lemon filling.  I'm not sure if this is a normal lemon meringue pie issue but it wasn't very pretty.   ORIGINAL REVIEW: I really liked this recipe with regard to taste but it makes absolutely no mention as to how long you should let it cool for and how (ie. in fridge or not).  I ended up cooling it for about an hour on a rack and then cooling it further in the fridge overnight.  I was concerned about it being runny (liquid kept running all over the place during the cooling process as all my floors are very uneven in my vintage apartment so I actually had to get a level out to find the most even place in on floor and cooled it on a table in the middle of the hall) so I tried a piece this morning and it was fantastic.  It set properly but the meringue had shrunk quite a bit although I think that this may have been my fault due to not beating long enough.  Also, a lot of users said 3/4 cup of lemon juice.  I got a lot more than that out of my two lemons but it wasn't too tart at all so I was happy.  Overall, good recipe but a few things needed clarification.  Will make it again.

text:
Excellent recipe. Next time I will make 1 1/2 times the filling. My pie pan might have been a 10" rather than 9". I like lots of filling. Meringue- I added 1/4 tsp cream of tartar to it. I made the meringue before the filling as one person suggested. The meringue didn't hold such stiff peaks when put on the pie. It wasn't a hot day but maybe with the oven on it was  a little warm for it. Next time I will beat it while the filling is cooking. I used 2 rather large lemons which yeilded about 1/2 cup juice. Very tasty.

text:
Phenomenal and easy to follow recipe. My first time making lemon meringue pie, and it came out GREAT the first time! My boyfriend thought it was to die for. The term "juice of 2 lemons" can be a bit misleading; the second time I made the recipe I used more lemon juice (still two lemons!) and it came out WAY too tart. Just a bit of warning! Other than that, and the tips on the site, it was great! Thanks for sharing!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/121587.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie was so good, and very easy. Make sure to use every bit of the meringue and spread it ALL the way across the crust - not even the very edges should be visible! It seems like way too much, but the meringue will shrink and weep and you will need every bit you've got. Here is my tip for saving time and trauma: I made the pie (minus the meringue) and put it in the fridge overnight. The next day, a few hours before serving, I reheated the pie in the oven while I whipped up the meringue, then topped and browned it. That way, you can avoid all the "issues" you run into with a typical meringue - topping it while piping hot, storing on counter/refrigerating, etc etc. Thanks for a keeper!
Review:

text:
This was my first lemon meringue pie, and it was a success! I labored over when to put the meringue on the lemon filling, as well as whether or not to refrigerate the pie. I decided to put the meringue on when the filling was piping hot, and not to put the pie in the fridge, and my co-workers raved about it. Also, I used milk instead of water, which made the filling more creamy in consistency.

text:
This would've gotten a 5 if the directions explained the cooling process.
This is my first time making meringue, and lemon pie for that matter.
The lemon filling turned out great. I used 3/4 cup of lemon juice instead of using real lemons and zest (not a big fan of the texture of zest). I wasn't sure how thick the mixture should be on the stove before putting it in to the crust, so I just guessed. It was a thick pudding consistency which seemed to be good.
The flavor was very tart and very good w/ the shortbread pie crust.
The meringue gave me some trouble. This is my first serious attempt and meringue, and it was SO fun making it. However, I wish I knew how to keep it from weeping so much. I attempted to make the meringue twice, both times, weeping like crazy that turned the pie crust soggy (still tasted ok though).

I might make this again but only when I learn how to keep meringue from oozing so much heh.

text:
I followed some of the other readers suggestions and increased the serving size to 12 so I would get proportionately more filling for my deep dish tray.  However, I did think that increasing the meringue was a little much for my taste.  My pie did weep a little.  I learned from another website that the filling has to be really hot (mine was) and that you have to make sure the meringue is totally cooked.  the weeping is from egg white seepage.  Wonderful recipe - will make again and again.  I felt like a rock star!!!

text:
This is THE recipe. As long as you know how to do meringue (i.e. warm pie shell, warm filling, then top etc) then this is it. The filling is perfect b/c it's not that mucky sweet stuff you buy in the store or find in some recipes. It has some tartness to it, which, if we're being frank, is what MAKES a lemon meringue pie what it is! Thanks so much for posting this recipe. Oh, and by the way - my dad who is a pie lover told me that this pie was better then his own mothers - and my dad just doesnt say stuff like that! I almost cried. Again - THIS IS IT!

What I liked about this recipe from the one I have used in the past is that I did not need to hurry to get the meringue done while the filling was still hot. Made it much easier. text:
This was my first time making lemon meringue pie.  I don't care for it myself, but it's my roommate's favorite so I made it to surprise her.  I did everything as stated in the recipe with the exception of whipping up some lemon juice in the meringue to compliment that of the custard. It ended up tasting fantastic! For someone who doesn't like LMP, I thought it was great and my roommate said it was the best she's ever had. I did make the mistake of (apparently) not sealing a part of the meringue to the crust and when I took it out of the oven, it leaked sticky stuff ALL over the counter as it was cooling. I don't know what happened!  ...but apparently it didn't make a difference because it turned out wonderfully.

text:
The directions could have been much clearer. For example, the sugar/lemon sauce begins to boil, then you add butter, but how long do you stir until sauce thickens? I stirred for 8 minutes and it still came out watery. 
Also, "whipping" the egg whites - I thought this meant with a fork or wisk but after 10 mins, still too runny. Was this supposed to be done with a mixer and if so, is cream of tarter a good ingredient to add? 
I put the pie in the fridge to speed up the cooling. The meringue shrank and formed dark drops on it. 
Will try another recipe.

text:
I made this pie today for my Dad since Mom hasn't made a homeade pie in a while, and it came out FABULOUS!  The recipe is so easy to follow, although I did alter a bit.  I used 1 1/2c sugar, 3 oz lemon juice, plus zest and juice from one lemon.  I also added 1 tsp of lemon extract, and 1 tsp of vanilla extract.  The meringue turned out perfect using a mixer.  This is definitely going into my recipe book.

Unbelievably good!! I tried making a lemon meringue pie last year (I am a newlywed and my husband would starve w/out this site) and it just did not work out! This recipe was easy to follow and the end product was amazing! I used one of the reviews to help me w/the meringue. Even though I have a kitchen aid I could not get it to form peaks. I added the 1/4tsp cream of tarter and 1/4 tsp vanilla and what do you know.. PEAKS FORMED! Thanks so much Grandma! I will be making this pie for my family for years to come :)

text:
My wife is a Lemon Meringue nut! She'd rather have Lemon Meringue than a cake on her birthday, and this is the recipe that I use. It maintains it's consistency and doesn't seem to melt like other pies I've made. I don't use the lemon zest, but I do kick in a little extra lemon juice, and a few dots of food coloring to get that nice yellow color. I like the idea of using a lemon extract, and I'll have to try that! Thanks!

text:
Great pie. Filling thickened but there was still water/liquid in the bottom of my pie pan when i cut into the pie. It's very humid where I live and I ended up adding an extra 2 tablespoons of sugar to the egg whites (even though there were no traces of yolk) so that they could form peaks. My friends and family enjoyed this pie. Recipe is a keeper.

text:
I have made a few lemon meringue pies before and this one was great! The only change I would make would be to make a day ahead, as we found the texture to be better the next day. (I did serve it cold after 6 hours in the fridge, but it just needed more time).  I added 1/2 cup lemon juice and it was PERFECT (no zest).  I added all the sugar called for, but only 1 1/4 cups water, which was the only mistake I made.  I should have added the full 1 1/2 cups water. Either way, it turned out fantastic and looks very impressive.

country:
None
text:
Very, very good recipe.  I followed it more or less with exceptional results.
I would say that I used a bit over a half cup of lemon juice.  For those who don't care for zest, I urge you to rethink.  Grandma probably didn't have a lemon zester, but a box type grater and she most likely used that.  I zested three lemons using the coarser side on the box grater, and the pie is very lemony, but no hunks of zest.
This is a keeper for sure.

text:
My husband is a huge fan of lemon meringue pie, and this one won the biggest thumbs-up.  Don't be afraid to cook the filling for awhile after the yolks are in.  Let it get nice and thick.  Tastes better (caramelization), and sets better.  I followed the suggestion to add a bit of sugar and vanilla.

country:
None
text:
I followed an earlier suggestion to increase the filling serving size to 12 ... sadly that just left me with an even greater amount of very runny filling!!  It tasted lovely, very lemony, but I think the instructions need to be a little clearer on how long to cook the filling/how thick it should get before going in the oven... mine looked reasonably thick on the stove, but in retrospect should have been cooked a fair bit longer. It also made the crust very soggy... I'm not sure where the fault lay in that, as I was using a ready made crust. The meringue part turned out pretty well, although it did separate despite my best efforts to seal the edges.  In summary, a good flavor but more details with respect to timing would be very helpful.

text:
This is one of the best lemon pie recipes I have ever had.  Everyone loved it.  I used the basic lemon filling part of the recipe and did use the suggestions by others and used milk instead of water.  I also did not use the flour and made the filling thicker by using 4 tablespoons of corn starch.  Then I used Meringue II for the topping and that was just perfect.

Update: two thumbs up! Hubby had 3 pieces, and for someone who doesn't like desserts all that much, that says alot! Thanks for the great pie! This is going in my recipe file... Original review:I wanted to make my husband a lemon meringue pie, since that is his favorite pie, and he was soooo sweet to me for Valentine's Day...flowers, house cleaned, dinner and breakfast...anyway, he waits every year for his mom to make him one for Thanksgiving, so I thought I would break tradition and surprise him with one. I had a pie crust and some lemons leftover from the BC Lemon chess pie, so I attempted it. I was soooo afraid I really messed this one up---forgot to bake the pie shell, forgot to out the butter in it---but it seemed to work out. I tasted the filling and it was awesome! Will update if he likes it, fingers crossed! (:

Display Name:
SHARONLF

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have tried this recipe twice now and am still perfecting it to try to get it to a 5 star rating. I followed the directions almost exactly the first time and it was a bit too tart for our taste so the second time I only zested one lemon. That was much better but I am still playing with the right amount of lemon juice. Juicing two medium lemons with an automatic juicer resulted in almost a whole cup of lemon juice which was a bit too much even though the pie was not runny. I have found that whisking the 1/4 cup hot sugar mixture into the egg yolks before adding them to the remaining mixture really helps the pie to set up well. The first time I didn't do this and the pie had some juice under the crust. My only other problem is with the meringue. It looks beautiful when the pie is finished and tastes great, but after being in the refrigerator for several hours the  meringue becomes sticky and makes the pie difficult to slice.  All in all I think that this is a very good recipe. There is never going to be a lemon  meringue pie that will be worth five stars to everyone since many people like different degrees of tartness. You just need to take a good recipe and tweak it until you get just the right degree of tartness for you. This is one of the best lemon pies recipies that I have tried.

country:
None
text:
Mmmm!  Perfect!  I wouldn't make any changes to this one (except to use milk instead of water), but I do have some tips and suggestions.  Strain the seeds and even the pulp of the lemons.  It is so much less stress this way, and your filling will be more decadent.  Make the meringue in the glass or metal bowl after you pour in the filling. It's okay if the filling cools, but it's not as okay to let your merinque dry out while you're waiting for the filling to cook.  And if you want the hefty poof of meringue like you see in the store-bought pies, I'd whip up a couple more egg whites. I adore this pie!  And the meringue was just picture-perfect coming out of the oven!

text:
Hmmm. I have been anxious to try this recipe for a while now. My husband LOVES lemon meringue and I make it at least once a month! I am from Europe and find American desserts on the sweet side. Alas this one was no different. I used 2 fresh lemons and measured over 1/4 cup juice. The meringue was a little looser than my normal recipe. It was tasty, I grant that! But it didn't hold itself anywhere near my normal recipe and it was a lot sweeter and creamier. I guess it depends on your taste! Bottom line is my husband asked me to go back to my own recipe. I would amend this recipe by adding a tad of white wine vinegar to the meringue to allow it stiffen a bit better and I would use free range eggs to get the more yellow color and a little less sugar. I also used milk in it which I think made it softer. I'll stick with water next time.

country:
None
text:
This was my first shot ever at homemade lemon meringue pie and it turned out pretty good.  I didn't have fresh lemons so I used 1/2 cup lemon juice.  I really enjoy the contrast of the tartness with the sweet meringue, but for those of you who don't like it so tart, I would suggest cutting down on the lemon juice.  I also added some yellow food coloring to the lemony part because a reviewer had said that the color was almost opaque and I thought that would be odd.  Overall, pretty easy to make and very good.  Will make again from time to time.

The pie was alright, but the filling was a little too sweet. I added about 1/3 of a cup of lemon juice. I used milk instead of the water. I probably wouldn't make this again because it's pretty time-consuming.

This was my first attempt at lemon meringue pie, per my daughter's Thanksgiving request. It was a last minute decision, so I got the first recipe I could find, but I'm so glad it was this one! This was perfect! It had the best level of tartness from the lemon and held together beautifully. I had leftover meringue from another recipe (which uses cornstarch to hold it together!), so I don't know how well the one included in this recipe would work, but the filling was fantastic! Will definitely be using this again!

None
country:
None
text:
This was a great recipe!
I made a few changes to make the flavour richer, lower in carbs and more lemony by using the juice and zest of an additional lemon and cutting back the water. I also tripled the butter and substituted processed sugar for erythritol at a 1:1 ratio to reduce the sweetness by 30%. I like my pies a little more tart. Finally I used a vanilla wafer crust instead of traditional pie crust. It came out sublime. We devoured it straight out of the oven, couldn't even wait for it to cool

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic recipe!  I took a few pieces of advice from the reviews, which I think made a big difference, especially putting the meringue on the lemon curd while the curd was still hot.  I also avoided using plastic wrap. I let the pie cool for about an hour and then put it in the fridge for another hour.  There was excess liquid and it held together better than any lemon meringue pie I've ever made.  A lot of the reviews recommend using milk.  I used water and was very happy with how it turned out- I plan to stick with that.  Next time I will increase the curd portion of the recipe by 50%- that's the only thing I plan to change.

country:
None
text:
Delicious! This was my first lemon meringue pie, and I nailed it with this recipe! Will definitely make again. Husband and kids loved it. I tweaked it slightly--used 1 1/4 cup sugar, 3 1/2 Tbs of cornstarch (ended up adding a smidge more). Beat the egg whites until they had stiff peaks, then baked according to the instructions. Let it sit on the counter to cool for an hour. Then put it in the fridge. It came out perfectly. No runny filling, no water, no meringue pulling away from the crust. Perfection.

I have finally found the Lemon Meringue Pie recipe that brings back the joy of Lemon Meringue pie from my youth.  As some members of the family are on low carb or diabetic:

Served it at a family party and everyone including the sugar eaters enjoyed it.  It got rave reviews from all. I will definitely be making this again. Thank you for posting this recipe.

text:
I love this recipe, I just had to redo the filling because in the video wasn't detailed enough and you have to separate the eggs before you start to boil the mixture so you can put it in right away. What I did because I was just following the recipe after I made the gel-like consistency for the filling I started to separate the eggs while the filling was still boiling so when I poured the eggs in and started mixing it went from the gel to a liquid form again. But when I re did it it was perfect, so kudos for that!

text:
Made it as directed. Used meyer lemons and filled it on a pre baked gluten free pie crust. Even the  gluten eaters in my family loved it. The filling set up perfectly and the meringue was beautiful!  On 2nd da, a wet knife was needed to cut thru the pie, bc the  sugars became quite  sticky after being in fridge. This is a keeper. Only lasted 2 at my house. Next time I may try to sub milk for the water and see if it makes it a little creamier. But this came together nicely and the flavor was fantastic just as it’s written here. Thanks Grandma!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The flavor was good, texture was so-so.  The recipe was not very detailed, so for someone making a lemon meringue pie for the first time, as I was, this is not the recipe I would recommend.  For example "juice of 2 lemons" is vague considering lemons range widely in size.  Especially in baking, you definitely want to know how much of a liquid you are putting in.  I figure this might account for some of my texture issues.  Also, I let the lemon custard sit in the pie shell and cool for about 10 minutes before topping with the meringue even though it didn't say so.  I just felt weird adding the meringue when the lemon was still steaming.

text:
I've made this pie two times now.--very good, very easy. The first time, the lemons were medium sized and I probably could have used a little less sugar. The second time I made the pie, the lemons were larger and I probably could have used a bit more sugar--2 - 4 tablespoons. However, there weren't any leftovers so no worries.   

Each time I made the pie, I made it  GF by omitting the flour and adding an extra tablespoon of cornstarch. texture was  great.

text:
This recipe is amazing as well. My family was hosting Christmas, and when we host we go all out on our food. I had made this recipe before, and my family ate almost all of it in 2 days because it was that good. So, for Christmas, I made 2 of them, and they were all gone. (Granted, we did have quite a few guests) My family loved it! Just one thing I would recommend it if you like a pie that is more lemony tasting, add about 1/2 lemon juice more than the recipe calls for, but leave out the extra lemon shavings. Add a bit more cornstarch so that it doesn't turn out runny. (We ran into this problem) Just adjust until it suits you!  Definitely recommend this recipe to everybody who is craving a good lemon meringue pie.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/912474.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the only lemon meringue pie I make. I make it exactly as the recipe says.

A few suggestions to help those who have not made this before...

I bake the pie crust...and make sure it is completely cool. Then I make the lemon custard...fill the shell and make sure that it is completely cool before putting the meringue on top. If you do not do this...it will make a syrup  maybe from the steam...but it is not pleasant. I have made this pie so many times now. And when you beat 5he egg whites and sugar.  if you add the sugar to the egg whites too fast...the peaks are not as stiff. You must add the sugar slowly...one tablespoon at a time and keep beating until those peaks are stiff.

I love the flavor of this pie..it is very easy...and deeelish...

userID:
4057580
Display Name:
vicsan
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

1

228

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely perfect! Like others have said, the flavor balance could not be better. It's not too tart and it's not too sweet. The lemon flavor is spot on! Grandma knew best, obviously. ;) 
I followed the recipe exactly, but doubled it and added 1/2 tsp. Vanilla to the meringue.  The texture was smooth and set up like it should.  Since I doubled the recipe, I used 3 large lemons and zest from two of them. The 3 lemons gave me exactly 1 cup of lemon juice. 
I let the pie cool on a rack for 2-3 hours and then put it in my pie carrier and refrigerated it in that. That worked well. 
I don't think I've had a better lemon meringue pie and I've been baking them and eating them for over 50 years.
One tip: Since this pie has so many ingredients, measure everything out before you start and separate your eggs to have them ready to go. I did make the meringue before I made the pie filling, but it sat a little too long and wasn't as stiff by the time I used it, so the next time I will just make the meringue while the pie is baking for 10 minutes. It's not any work for me with a Kitchen Aid mixer, so why not?
I highly recommend this pie! You will not be disappointed. It's delicious!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2019-02-10T21:28:25.747
helpfulCount:
0

country:

text:
I feel it’s a very good recipe, and I added quite a bit of lemon juice to make it more tart because that’s where my family likes it… And I was working with locally milled flower which tends to need some moisture added to it anyway so that worked out well. Are used European style butter which I think gives more richness because it has a higher butterfat content.Are used organic cane sugar rather than straight white sugar and it came out beautifully… Along with being healthier,  I find that the cane sugar has a really lovely flavor, which adds to the overall  bouquet of any given dessert. Also, I was blessed way back in the 90s to buy a Krupps electric hand mixer, which was actually made in the Republic of Ireland ????!  it has wire whisk style beaters rather than the flat blade saw and it does a beautiful job with making meringue. Haven’t tasted it yet and yet somehow I think it’s going to be delicious! Thank you so much for sharing this family recipe!

userID:
23622010
Display Name:
Hannah-Beth
isPro:

3

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5946413.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For a nice, fluffy dome of meringue, use 6 egg whites and   9 tablespoons of sugar. To prevent “weeping”, put meringue on filling AS SOON as the filling is put in the pie crust shell - a piping hot filling will cook the meringue on the bottom and prevent that film of water from forming. To prevent the little droplets on the meringue, beat the sugar in very patiently, no more than a tablespoon at a time. The droplets form either because of granulated sugar undissolved in the egg whites or because of over-beating the eggs. I’ve also found that 10 minutes of baking is perfect to cook the meringue without burning it.
Review:
Rating:
1
dateLastModified:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yes, it is a simple recipe, but the first thing I noticed was there was no measurements for the lemon juice or zest. Big lemons, little lemons... each will give different amounts of juice and zest.  Mine were on the bigger side, so I ended up with a pucker up lemon meringue pie. Second, 4 egg whites leaves you with a pitiful amount of actual meringue.  It could easily be doubled or tripled.  The end result was a bit watery as well.  Over all, I wouldn't use this recipe again.

text:
The pie itself wasn't difficult to make, but it took me forever to get the meringue to set. I'm sure I did something wrong.  I probably wouldn't have zested the lemons as much as I did next time. I was sure to zest the entire lemon. It was a very pretty yellow color though. If I wanted another lemon meringue pie in the future I'd probably use this recipe since it was so easy except I might substitute cool whip or whip cream instead of the meringue.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3794500.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To help it not separate I kept the lemon part in the warm pan until I had meringue ready, made sure meringue went to the edge of the crust and left the pie in the oven for an hour after the 10 minutes of baking. I turned the oven off and opened the door halfway. After that hour I cooled it on the counter for another hour before putting in the fridge for a couple hours. I was SO excited that it didn’t separate!!  I’ve made this recipe three times this week and love it very much.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night and followed the directions exactly.  It was delicious.  Those who said it was watery probably did not whip the egg whites long enough.  I probably did for 10 minutes.  When it says it's ready when "stiff peaks" form, make sure the peaks do not ooze back into the bowl  when you stop whipping or you have not whipped long enough.  There is no way this is watery once the egg whites are whipped long enough.  It also says to use a metal or glass bowl, which I did, as I do for whipping cream, because plastic and whipping egg whites and cream do not work properly together.   Guaranteed success when the egg whites are whipped long enough and a serious pleaser for lemon pie lovers.
Review:

5

text:
Delicious! We love this pie! The only thing I did different was use ALMOST 1/2 c. of bottled lemon juice instead of real lemons. I also used rounded tbl of flour, but leveled tbl for the corn starch. Lemon pudding came out perfect! Just have to stir for a good 10 minutes or so. For the meringue, I did add a bit of vanilla extract. Comes out perfect every time. I do have to drain the pie after it has cooled in the fridge. That's okay, the end result is pure lemon heaven!

text:
I added more lemon juice because we love a super-lemony taste.
Very easy to make. Yes, it takes several bowls and some thought but it comes out perfect if you follow the instructions.
I used a simple but delicious pie crust. The pie crust has to be baked to within 10 minutes of completion before the pie filling is added and the meringue.
If you make the meringue first so you can put it on top of the hot filling, it won't weep.

text:
This was delicious, but I followed another old recipe I used some time ago along with this one and I omitted the flour and instead just used one half cup cornstarch with one cup of sugar, one and a half cups water with half cup fresh lemon juice (2 lemons). I only had a plastic mixing bowl to beat my meringue in so it kinda didn’t high peak on me or get too stiff like I usually make it, but it still got good and golden in toaster oven for about twelve minutes and tasted great with the half cup sugar! I let my pie sit out on the stove and cool for about an hour plus fifteen minutes before placing it in the refrigerator.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great lemon meringue pie; I gave it 4 stars because I tweaked the recipe to get what I wanted. I used 1-1/2 times the recipe, used the juice and zest from 3 nice, big lemons. Since it's really humid around here, I stabilized the meringue by adding a cooled, cooked cornstarch and water mixture to the egg whites. That worked out fine. The end result was a lemon meringue pie that had a lemony tang and a meringue that was gorgeous. While the recipe itself is a keeper, I'm going to work my revisions into it. Thanks!

Everyone is always asking me to make this.  
I am extremely picky about my eggs too. And I only use cage free, organic , humane certified ones.  It makes all the difference in the way the meringue tastes and peaks.

text:
Only change I ran into is one lemon was hard as a rock, so I had to resort to lemon juice for the second lemons worth. I made the pastry crust from scratch, probably over beat it, but the meringue I whipped for about 15 minutes it was so fluffy! Unlike the running meringue soup I had made on my first attempt at this pie. I made sure not to have a smidgen of yolk mixed in my egg whites before whisking. I made one last mistake, turned on a low broil to brown top, wish I hadnt done that, a light golden would have been perfection.

userID:
16832747
Display Name:
Born2Bake
isPro:

6

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4025276.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the cooling recommendations from other reviewers - 1hr counter, 3 in fridge, then tent with foil. I also set the recipe to 12 servings, which was the perfect amount of both filling and meringue. I made my own crust and made sure to BAKE it before adding filling and meringue. I'm poor so I don't have a fancy kitchen with automatic mixers and counter space, but was still able to coordinate the boiling/thickening of the filling with the whipping of the meringue. This timing is critical. It is vital to seal the hot filling with meringue as soon as possible. Any delay will effect how your meringue cooks and looks.

Experiment with different amounts of lemon juice, but just under 1/2 cup was very lemon-e and I would probably cut back next time. Remember, I was using the recipe set at 12 servings.

Tasty and beautiful.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
This is delicious! I made it simple: I whisked all of the ingredients for the lemon filling together in a cold saucepan until the flour and corn starch were smoothly blended in, then turned stove on med-high, constantly stirring with the whisk until the mixture was boiling and thickened to perfection.  I poured it into a pre-baked Marie Callender's (frozen) crust and it came out perfectly! Leave to cool 1 hr., then refrigerate 3-4 hrs. before cutting.

Display Name:
Sandra Patterson Lewis
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was Lemon Meringue Pie Day. And a sunny, warm and really a perfect summer day. So why not try making a lemon meringue pie?

Now I’ve never made a real one… just a couple of those out of the box ones. And since we have drastically reduced our processed food consumption, that isn’t an option. So lemon meringue pie from scratch it is. (I did buy a pre-made pie crust. Making pie crust from scratch scares me! And since my local store had them on sale $1.25 for two shells, I probably saved money).

A search on the internet revealed 1000s of recipes. So which one to choose? Then I saw “Grandma’s Lemon Meringue Pie” with over 1,700 reviews and 4+ stars on allrecipes.com. Of course, a Grandma is going to have a great recipe. And it had simple ingredients and and easy to follow instructions.

Decision made, time to get into the kitchen and start baking. I generally prefer recipes that require one bowl, mix everything in and then dump everything in a pan and bake. Realizing that Grandma’s Lemon Meringue Pie would not be everything I hoped for with that method, I resolved to take my time and be patient with every step.

As I tasted the filling and then watched the meringue grow in my mixing bowl, my optimism increased that this may actually turn out to be something yummy and pretty!! Ten minutes of baking time later and presto – a mound of meringue and a tasty lemon pie underneath.

city:

country:
None
text:
This is a perfect recipe. Meyer lemons add fragrance, flavor and color and I use them when I have them. Have made it many times. 

If bakers are having problems with moisture in the pie, there are two tips to avoiding that. Be sure the crust is completely cool so it isn't releasing heat/condensation into the filling, and don't overcook the filling. Cornstarch loses some of its "oomph" as it cooks. When the filling boils the cornstarch is at maximum thickening strength, continued cooking will not yield greater thickness. It's all downhill from there so remove it from the heat.

text:
Everyone is pretty right about this one - it's definitely a "keeper" - I did use a frozen regular pie crust and baked it the day I made the filling.  I didn't want to fill it, however, as I was serving it the next day and thought it might get soggy.  The next day I reheated the filling a "bit", filled the pie shell and made the meringue, put it on and baked.  Turned out divine !  And I did add a bit of Creme of Tartar to the egg whites.  It was a gorgeous looking pie and tasted just as good.
Thanks for the wonderful recipe for my favorite pie.

text:
WARNING!  Definitely add cream of tartar as needed to make the meringue.  I used egg whites and no matter how long and fast I whipped them, it was still soup.  ADD the CREAM OF TARTAR!  I added 1/4 tsp at a time until the meringue made.  Other than that, that is the only thing I would change.  The lemon custard filling is wonderful.

text:
My first attempt at making a lemon meringue pie and it was delicious!  Just as the name implies it tastes just like the ones my Grandma used to make.  I followed the recipe exactly using the juice from 2 lemons.  The lemons came from our lemon tree so they were on the large size.  If using store bought lemons which tend to be smaller I'd recommend using 3.  I also used farm fresh eggs provided by my neighbor's chickens.  No eggs are better  for baking.

country:

text:
This was EXCELLENT. It was my first time making a lemon meringue pie so I was a bit intimidated. I also made my own pie crust for it.  I  read a lot of the reviews and found them helpful and took some advice: used 1/2 c fresh lemon juice (so either 2-3 lemons depending on their size) and 1T lemon zest. I baked my crust for 9 minutes at 350 before filling it. I did let the pie set out on a cookie sheet for one hour after baking and then put it in the refrigerator overnight to solidify.  I did have some beads of "sugary moisture" on the top but not too bad.  I thought the amount of meringue to filling was appropriate as written and I followed the directions as written with the exceptions noted above.

text:
We had this pie for dinner last night.  Yum!

Here are the small changes we made:
Gluten free pre made crust - didn't notice the difference.
3/4 cup sugar instead of 1 cup.
Meyers lemons from our tree had plenty of sweetness.
Used all the zest from the lemons for extra tang.
Only had three egg whites (don't ask), so added 3.5 T of sugar and had a slightly thinner meringue topping.
The steps take a while but aren't hard.
The result was exactly what we were hoping for.
Thanks!

text:
This was the first pie I've ever made and it turned out pretty good for a first time, especially after reading how technical lemon meringue pies are.  So I totally missed the word "baked" after pie crust so needless to say my crust is not baked. So hopefully others wont make that mistake.  The only thing I think needs to be stressed in this recipe is to seal the crust with the meringue because if you've never made it before you don't know why and maybe wont pay too much attention to that. It turns out it's really important. When I moved my pie from the oven to the table the lemon stuff was watery and dripped everywhere. Overall the taste is really good though.

My Grandmother was an awesome pie maker.  Her pies were to die for.  I found this recipe to make to go with seafood gumbo for Christmas.  When I tasted the filling, it knocked my socks off! I had flashbacks of Mawmaw Strick's pie!  (It warmed my heart,)  When I whipped up the meringue and put it on that pie, I could have sworn that she was in my kitchen. It was beautiful.  Being it was Christmas morning, I was stressed and didn't take a picture of it.  Believe me, it was picture ready.  Everyone loved it.  Word: make sure that you used a deep dish pie crust.  I kept fretting on the drive that the meringue was going to slide off.  It didn't!  Make this pie, it is indeed "Grandma's "

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Normally, this would be a dish loaded with pitfalls.  Can't believe my Mom had to make this pie from a simple recipe with no guidance.  Thanks to the All Recipes community, it all turned out great.  I used the Graham Cracker Crust I in a 9" Pyrex pie plate.  I kept the serving size at 8, but will ramp it up to 10 next time for a little bit more filling.  I made the meringue with SIX egg whites BEFORE I made the lemon curd and that was sage advice.  Stopped stirring the lemon curd/egg yolk mixture at the first sign of a boiling bubble.  Put it in the center of the oven for some delicately browned wisps of meringue and you have a winner.

text:
First of all NO ONE believed that I made this pie homemade! It looked beautiful and tasted just as well. 

I made this with frozen pie dough and although it tasted fine I would probably use a prepared Nilla Wafer Tin next time just as an experiment. With that being said  It came out beautifully, we drove two hours for Thanksgiving and the Pie did get condensation during the drive (totally my fault for completely covering it!) 

I dont have a zester so I use a parmeasan grater and the zest turned out well, it's amazing to see it completely dissolve to form the creamy curd! It was my first attempt and mixing the yolk in this fashion and although I was intimidated it was easy and I'm excited to try again! 

I would use more zest next time (I used less than the recommended amount) but I like it very tart. 

Overall wonderfully balanced recipe!

text:
It is an excellent recipe and does not require any tweaking. I use half a cup of lemon juice. I have used this recipe for years. However, there is a glitch in the recipe on my phone. The correct amount is 1 C to make the lemon filling and 6T to make the meringue. The app on my phone incorrectly says 6T for both. I got on my laptop and got the correct (1C + 6 T) from the website. Hope this helps the app users.

I wouldn't change a thing!  It held together without getting all dewy after a few days (leftovers).  My 12 year old granddaughter made this and it was the most delicious lemon pie I have ever eaten!  She zested the ENTIRE yellow on the lemons (a little white got in there too but it didn't affect the taste) When I went to check on her at the stove it wasn't thickening.  I asked her if she put in 3 "tablespoons" of cornstarch and OPPS she had used teaspoons.  I added 2 tablespoons and getting it to blend into hot lemon wasn't easy but I poured it in the piecrust I had made earlier and it was just fine!   This will now be a regular at Thanksgiving.  Made it for Christmas too!  Note to ALL:  Use homemade pie crust - frozen, store bought ruined it.

text:
Curd tastes great, I make my meringue with the recipe off of the cream of tartar bottle like my grandmother did.  My meringue kept spraying from the curd and shrinking.  I have learned you MUST PUT THE MERINGUE ONTO PIPING HOT FILING AND SEAL TO THE EDGES WELL.  This prevents the water and separation. Can't wait til next time when I finally nail this beast!

text:
great lemony favor!! I tripled (24 servings) this recipe and made some slight changes.  When I modified it called for 3 cups sugar but I ended up with about 2. I combined 1c sugar, flour, CS, and mixed in the wet...lemons ended up being about 1.5c lemon. It is absolutely vital you temper the eggs before adding to your sugar mixture...I scooped about 1-2c of the mixture and blended with egg yokes then added to the main pot.

I did not bake the pastry blind so that it shrunk and made less room for the filling so next time I will do the blind baking first. Because of this fact the pastry rose all over the place in little mounds LOL but I poured the filling on anyway and it ran over the pastry. (maybe a bigger pan would have been better).  However the filling tasted great and I was very happy with the ease that this was made.  The meringue came out a bit flat as it cooled but it was my first pie.  I was happy with the taste and will definitely try this again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/827909.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time making a Lemon Meringue Pie - After reading a majority of the reviews, I made the following substitutions to each pie; First I changed the servings to 24 for two pies) (12) was not enough for 2 (9"-Deep Shells)
1. Added zest from (4) lemons along with 3/4 of a cup of lemon juice.
2. Added 4 tbsps of cornstarch
3. Added 2 tbsps of Lime juice
As noted by several I made the Meringue beforehand to ensure that I was ready to add it while the filling was still hot.  Both pies turned out great, everyone really liked them.  One question: I let the pies stand in an open rack for 1.5 hrs to cool prior to wrapping them in suran-wrap.  When I went to served them 4 hours later from the frig the Meringue seemed to have collapsed a little, although my Meringue was almost 4 inches deep - if anyone can suggest another method to keep the shape I'd appreciate it.....Thx Jake

text:
This turned out perfect!!  Well, all except my crust was ugly but that was my fault lol.  I used meyer lemons straight from my lemon tree for the lemon filling.  The filling did scare me because it was pretty soupy when it went onto the pie crust and after the 10 minute bake so I let it sit on the counter for a while and it was still pretty jiggly, so I threw it in the fridge and after a couple hours it was perfect!!  Set up so nicely and the flavor was exploding with lemon and the meringue...perfect!!  So glad I made this recipe and I followed one reviewers and loosely covered with foil when storing to avoid water forming.

text:
This was my first attempt at making a Lemon Meringue Pie. This recipe was simple and easy to follow. I followed a few others tips: After pouring custard into crust, I let it stand and cool before placing meringue on top.  Also, once it was taken out of the oven, I let it cool and set for an hour before placing in the refrigerator.  Once cooled, it was a nice sweet treat.

text:
Followed the recipe exactly.  Should change the title to "Delicious lemon liquid with meringue on top".  Curd didn't set, no where on the recipe does it say to chill the curd first in the pie shell to set and then top with meringue...if you put meringue on top of hot curd it's going to make a pool of water at the bottom of the pie shell.  That's what happened to mine.  Like I said, I followed this EXACTLY, and I had curd that wasn't set, and a pool of melted meringue on the bottom of the pie tin.  Delicious slop.

The taste of the pie was ok, but it came out very runny.  I cooked the curd until "thickened" (I know everyone's definition is different) and I did exactly what the recipe called for.  I think one issue was the recipe doesn't say exactly how much lemon juice to use.  I have my own lemon tree, and they come in all sizes.  Maybe I added too much. text:
Delicious filling!!!!  I have never made lemon meringue pie without using boxed cook and serve lemon pudding.  But my daughter and I were having a craving for it, and we had no pudding.  So I found this recipe and we decided to try it.  Delicious and relatively easy, though definitely more time consuming than making with the boxed pudding.  I made it exactly as the recipe is written, but then added 1T of bottled lemon juice in the last couple minutes of cooking to add a little more tartness - I guess it depends on the size of your lemons, and mine were on the small size.  Next time, I will double the recipe to make a fuller pie, and then eat the remainder as pudding.  Yum!  Thanks for the great recipe!  (I did not make the meringue - my rating is simply for the filling.)

text:
I love this recipe !   I've made it at least 3 times if not more.  My husband LOVES it too !  I have cheated a bit.  I am not one to separate eggs or zest and squeeze lemons.  So, I put 3 whole eggs in the yellow part, I put lemon juice in and I bought dried lemon peel online for the zest.  I also add extra lemon juice than would be 2 lemons.  I put 4 ½ ounces of lemon juice and 3 Teaspoons/1 Tablespoon of the lemon peel in. It kind of needed some extra flavor and that does it nicely.  I also buy egg whites at the grocery store and make the meringue that way.
My husband LOVES lemon meringue pies and I dont' mind making this for him.  I love it too !

text:
This was a wonderful pie to eat! Make sure you are a good multitasker in the kitchen as you will have lots of things cooking at once. Make sure that when making the meringue you do not have any egg yolks mixed in with the whites, this will cause your meringue to stay very liquidy. I accidentally dropped a yolk in my meringue and had to remake it! Though I enjoyed cooking and eating this pie, it is not for beginners.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great lemon meringue pie recipe, quite a bit of work but worth it. 
I used a 10 inch pie plate, so I changed the servings to 10, but should have changed it to 12 as there was only slightly more than an inch of filling. 
I also added the juice and rind of one lime that I wanted to use up, but it didn't take away from the lemony goodness. The meringue would not brown at 350 after 15 minutes and I didn't want to cook the whole pie, so I punched up the oven to 450 while leaving the pie in and it was done in less than 5 minutes.
It was well received, everyone loved the balance of sweet and tart. I will make it again.

Display Name:
anna duval

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/760283.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time for a meringue and it's a fabulous pie due to a great recipe and some helpful tips from other reviewers. Changes I made:  used 3.5 Tbsp cornstarch; 1/2c lemon juice (3 lemons) with zest of 1 lemon; added 1 tsp vanilla extract in filling; 5 Tbsp sugar (1 Tbsp less than recipe) in meringue; used 1c milk + 1/2c water (all water in recipe). Whisked everything, boiled 1 minute then added tempered yolks and boiled another minute. Baked pie crust 20 min at 390 then put filling in warm pie crust and topped meringue on warm filling.  Takes 10-12 minutes to beat egg whites and sugar into meringue. Baked 10 minutes; cool 2 hours then fridge 6 hours until was home again to try it! Wonderful!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2016-03-08T08:00:26.943
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
1947601
Display Name:
Debutante
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
59
favoritesCount:
209
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6359594.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very nice, fresh lemon flavour. When cooking the filling, it didn't take long for it to thicken up. Once it came to a boil the first time, I reduced the heat to medium-low and continued to cook it for an additional 5 minutes. Then, I let it cool in a bowl for about 30 minutes before spreading it in the baked crust. The texture and consistency turned out very nice. The first time I made this recipe I added vanilla, as one reviewer suggested, but we did not care for it AT ALL. It totally overpowered the lemon and ruined the pie.
As for the meringue, don't believe anyone who tells you that you cannot "over whip" a meringue -- you definitely CAN! It will become foamy and dry and not hold a proper peak. (I learned this the hard way!) Be sure to start with room-temperature egg whites and check the "peaks" often once you get past the soft-peak stage.

text:
It  came out perfectly even though I was in an emergency baking situation, and I did not have all the ingredients (fine sugar for example or cornstarch - I used flour instead). I also changed the water for milk, and put only one lemon juice and one zest. 
Finally, for the filling part, I use my mother's secret which makes impossible to mess the desired "solid" texture in any flour/cornstarch filling: I mix all liquids and dry ingredients together before putting the pan on the stove on medium, and whisk it without stopping for 14 minutes. It came out perfect: tasty, right texture, lemony... Nice birthday pie for me!

I used one lemon and its zest, and substituted 3 tablespoons of lemon juice for the second lemon. Had no trouble whatsoever. Filling was awesome and the meringue came out beautifully. Probably should have used an 8 inch pie pan rather than 9, but still, I have no complaints! I absolutely recommend this and definitely will make again!  *as a side note, a beginner cook might need more instruction on how to tell when the filling or the meringue were ready, but the experienced baker should have no problem.

text:
Delicious!  This was my first time making lemon meringue pie and it turned out wonderfully. I didn't have large lemons, just the lemons from a  neighbor's tree, so I juiced enough for 1/2 c. like recommended. I also used almost a cup of whole milk and the rest water cause I didn't know if I should stick with water or do all milk. I also used a tsp of cream of tarter when making the meringue to help with weeping. I totally forgot the lemon zest, which I actually took the time to get. Anyway, it took forever to juice all those little lemons and get the seeds and pulp out, but I had my kid help with mixing the meringue. Overall, I'd say it's worth it. I'll be making this again.

country:
None
text:
This recipe is very good.  The only thing I would change is to cut the amount of sugar in the curd filling from 1 cup to 3/4 cups or 2/3.  The meringue part and the pie crust are already sweet and with the whole cup of sugar in the curd filling, it makes the pie really sweet.  More tartness will add a nicer balance overall.  If you like things on the sweeter side, stick to this recipe.  Everyone approved of this pie.  :)

city:
