country:
None
text:
This pie is fabulous.  The only change I made was adding 1/4 tsp of cream of tartar to the meringue.  My wife loves lemon meringue pie and thought this pie was as good or better than the best she had ever had.  That is high praise from her as her mom made a fabulous lemon meringue.  I made the meringue before I made the lemon filling.  I put the meringue on while the lemon filling was hot.  After cooking I let the pie sit out for an hour and then refrigerated it for 3.  It was perfect.  I had no excess liquid in the pie.  This was the first lemon meringue pie I ever made.  I found the video to be very helpful.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I chose this recipe for my first ever attempt at making a lemon meringue pie. It is the best tasting lemon meringue pie I've ever had!

I love the simplicity of the recipe. I expected it to take a while to make one, but I had it prepared and in the oven within 40 minutes!

 I made the mistake of putting the pie filling in the shell while I was making the meringue, so it had cooled down considerably before getting the meringue on the pie and baking it in the oven. It resulted in a weeping pie :(  

Next time I make it, I will make sure to put the meringue on the pie while the custard is still piping hot!

More importantly, my husband loved it!  I followed this recipe to the letter, however I did make a couple of changes.  For the filling I used 1 1/4 cups of sugar, 3 1/2 tablespoons of cornstarch, 1/2 cup fresh lemon juice (my husband loves it to be tarty) and lemon zest from 2 lemons.  It turned out perfectly!  I've been trying to make this pie for 23 1/2 years.  Finally I can make it and I will make it, a lot more times!

text:
The flavor is great!  My issues were not with the recipe bt with my technique.  This was the first time I ever attempted this pie (pies are not my specialty though I am an intermediate level baker).  My curd was a bit gritty and the meringue seperated; like others mentioned, I had a sticky, lemony water pool at the bottom when I cut it. Oddly enough, this did not affect the crust.  I let it cool to room temp before putting it in the fridge so I don't think it was condensation as others suggested.  I rated it a three because there were some directions missing - like pre-baking the pie crust; novice bakers should be given those instructions.  Also there could be some hint as to the curd and how to make sure it was smooth.

Made To recipe. But as per review voted most helpful, boiled lemon filling for 14 minutes. DO NOT do that because you only get a few mm of filling at the bottom!!! Take it off heat right after it boils, thickens and then put the meringue on. Tastes good, but don't overboil or you'll be as disappointed as I was :( after waiting all day to dig in.

text:
Just finished eating my first slice of this pie--fabulous!  

I definitely agree with the former reviewers:  substitute 2% MILK for water and use 1/2 cup of lemon juice and 1 TB of zest.  Finally, I also like a lot of meringue, so I added three egg whites (I needed the yolks for an icebox pie I had made last week) to the four in the recipe (and added a little extra sugar when whipping).

You'll love the creamy texture--so good!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
For some reason I struggled with this recipe.  First time it was soupy and didn't set.  And it took forever to whip the meringue into stiff peaks.  Second time I added more cornstarch (in water) and it set really thick.  So if it's a little soupy it should still set fine.  For meringue: beat eggs, then add 1 tbsp sugar at a time, beat more, etc,  but not too much or else meringue will set too stiff.

text:
Easy to make and delicious! I made additional gluten free ramekins for myself in addition to the pie. 

I increased the recipe by half, used Bob's all purpose gluten free flour in place of the regular flour. 

Pour the lemon filling directly into ramekins and seal with meringue & bake 10 minutes. 

It's just as delicious, and an easy way to please both wheat eating pie lovers AND gluten free guests without much hassle!

text:
Turned out as described in recipe it would. I added cream of tartar 1/4 tsp and 1 tsp vanilla to meringue as I was whipping it. Smooth creamy light flavor from meringue. And I added yellow food coloring as needed to get s more yellow color to pie filling. My crust was still cooling so I slammed it into freezer to cook it faster, and the filling was already made n hot so I dumped it in s large bowl n stirred often so it could cone down heat wise but not enough to form a film on top before I put filling into cooked pie crust from freezer. In other words, it won’t hurt to have filling done before crust is totally cooked. I took a picture......

country:
None
text:
Instructions are too vague. It wasn't clear to me how long I should cook the filling and to what thickness. I also wasn't sure about the whipping time for the meringue. I watched the accompanying video and attempted to replicate those textures, which took quite a long time. About 25 minutes on the stove to thicken the filling, and over 15 minutes of whipping the meringue. I put the pie in the fridge after letting it cool on the counter for about 15 minutes. It was loosely covered with the plastic pie crust lid, plenty of room around the edges, as the meringue prevented closure. The final product had a puddle of meringue-flavored liquid in the bottom. So disappointed. The flavor was okay. but I won't bother with this recipe again.

My husband requested lemon meringue pie for his birthday today.  I was a little nervous.  Every time I have ever made lemon meringue it has had the juice at the bottom or something has gone wrong with the meringue.  NOT TODAY!  The lemon filling was incredible.  Perfect balance. Lemon Meringue pie is my husbands favourite - I will make this again and again.  It was extremely easy.

text:
Fabulous Lemon Meringue Pie!  My husband & kids loved it and I thought I was going to be the only one who liked it.  
I did use a graham cracker crust, but would be good with a regular pie crust as well.
The only thing I might do different next time is change the meringue a little based on another recipe where I love the meringue (really sits tall on the pie & yummy) and it would be to use: 4 egg whites, 1 cup sugar, 1/4 tsp cream of tarter & 1/4 tsp vanilla extract.  
This is definitely going to be made on a regular basis now that I know everyone here loves it.

text:
I am a frequent baker, and this is the first meringue pie that I've ever made that wept! I got a watery layer between my meringue and my filling that I had to pour out after it cooled for a little bit. The flavor was otherwise spot-on, just as you would expect from a lemon meringue. I also used 1/2 c juice and zest from 1 lemon. I'll give it 4 stars on taste but I think I'll stick to my usual lemon meringue recipe next time since my usual recipe doesn't weep.

text:
I don't see why people are saying the curd layer was thin, mine filled up a tender-flake deep dish 9" shell with a bit left over (However I did use the juice of one more lemon). Meringue never works our for me so what I do is cool the filling a bit and then spoon marshmallow fluff straight from the jar onto the pie (not spreading it too much)and then brown it at 500°F for 3 minutes. It works nice, it's not as thick as traditional meringue though

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm an experienced baker, but had never attempted a lemon meringue pie until I made this recipe this weekend. We had some lemons on our Meyer lemon tree, and this was the perfect way to use them. I was honestly surprised at how easy it was to make, and making the meringue was a breeze. I put the meringue on while the filling was still hot to ensure that they wouldn't separate from each other. I let the pie cool on the counter for an hour before putting it in the refrigerator to chill and then let it set up overnight. My husband had a slice and then went back for seconds. That pretty much says it all. If you're intimidated by making meringue, this recipe makes it easy.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe.  Since we like a more lemony pie,  I used 1/2 c lemon juice (lemons vary in juiciness).  I also make the filling in the microwave.  Follow the directions given except use a glass bowl and after adding yolks microwave for 1 minute at a time, whiskig between, untill quite thick.  This whole process takes less than 10 minutes.  I also slightly under-bake my crust and put everything together while still warm.

text:
I had never made a lemon meringue pie until today, so I don't know what I'm talking about, but this turned out pretty darn well. =) I used a 10" saute pan for the filling and whisked almost continuously; it thickened up very quickly. I also followed suggestions from several other reviews: since I was using a 10" pie plate, I upped the servings to 12; I used milk in place of the water; I spread the meringue over the hot filling and sealed it to the edges; I cooled it on the counter for three hours and didn't refrigerate it at all. I'll be trying this again. =)

text:
It was my first time making a lemon meringue pie, and it came out as close to perfect as it could with my current cooking skills. Just make sure you chill it for long enough, or it might not set properly. I did 1 hr at room temperature, then a few more hours in the fridge, according to others' instructions.
I made sure to have the meringue prepared before the filling boiled, so that the bottom of the meringue would cook from the filling's heat, but it strangely seemed to deflate a bit once it hit the filling. When it came out of the oven, though, there was plenty of meringue height.

text:
I didn't feel like reading all the reviews and doing the recipe tweaking today, so I didn't. This recipe is just fine how it is!!! My uncle asked for a lemon meringue pie for his birthday. I wasn't sure if the texture was right because I'd never had lemon meringue before but he said it was perfect!! His family loved it, too! And I loved the lemon curd part--it was not too sweet but not too tart... I'm not a big fan of the texture of meringue but I enjoyed this pie for the lemony goodness. 

sn: I'm so glad I had a stand mixer for the meringue!!!! It didn't even take the 30 minute prep time because I had the meringue whipping while I was cooking the lemon curd and pie crusts.

text:
Great tasting recipe! I gave it four stars because, as with other members, mine fell apart and my meringue started weeping and dripping. I'm not sure what I did wrong, as I'm an experienced baker. I think it might have been that I put too much filling into the pie, not allowing the meringue to completely touch the sides of the pie. My crust turned out soggy and the pie had to be scooped out. I'll try this again, but maybe tweak something in the filling so it doesn't fall apart the way it did.

They stiffen better.

text:
Apparently I am one of the few reviewers who did not like this recipe.  I have made many lemon meringue pies and this was the first time I've had a problem with the lemon filling thickening adequately before pouring it into the pie crust.  Yes, I did double check my measurements and did bring the filling to a full rolling boil and beyond.  Consequently it was impossible to put the meringue on the hot filling which is the recommended method of preparing a lemon meringue pie.  I will not be making this recipe again.

We all loved this! I did have a problem with the meringue. I checked with my baking specialist (my mom :) ) and she said that she normally only uses 2 egg whites with 4tbls of sugar. text:
I was really optimistic about this pie after tasting the custard and the meringue Pre-baking.  Both were super tasty and I was psyched about how it would turn out.   I took others advice and subbed milk for water and it was creamy and yummy.  I baked the crust, made the meringue and then made the custard so I could follow the directions to top the hot filling.  10 minutes later I took it out to cool and that's when it went downhill.  5 minutes out of the oven the meringue started to weep and shrink.  Now it's a shrunken meringue sitting on a pool of syrup over the tasty custard.  Really not sure what went wrong, but I still rate the 3 stars because the separate parts are so tasty.

text:
This is a perfect balance of tartness and sweetness. I used 3 golf-ball sized lemons for this recipe. I'm not a fan of meringue, so instead I used whipped topping with a touch of piping gel (to stiffen it up so it would hold its shape after I piped it). Of course I baked the pie for 10 minutes and let it cool before I added the whipped topping. A fan favorite!

sweet_thickness
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
ZEST, ZEST, ZEST, my first bite left me with a bitter mouthful. I have never had a lemon meringue pie that you had to actually chew on zest to swallow. Although I did not like the zest the pie had a good texture, so I will follow the advice of some other reviewers and leave out the zest or just add a 2 Tblspns.  The meringue was excellent! It takes a while to form, but well worth the wait. There is no need to add tartar. I used an electric mixer on high to get the foamy egg whites then very slowly added the sugar. I then turned the mixer down to a medium speed and let it do its thing for about a half an hour and it came out perfect.

text:
This is an excellent recipe, much easier than the Lemon Meringue Pie III! Instead of juicing the lemons myself, I used the contents of one whole lemon-shaped squeeze bottle of lemon juice. I also replaced the sugar with Splenda and it turned out great! Since this pie was going to sit out for a while, I added 1/2 tsp of vinegar and cream of tartar to the meringue and a packet of unflavored gelatin to the lemon custard. Yum!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent and yummy pie recipe!!  Definitely worth the extra work this pie and all its steps take!  My first attempt was complete success and yielded the perfect sweet and tangy combination.  I highly recommend using the fresh lemons, over bottled lemon juice.  Lessons learned from my second attempt: Temper the lemon into the egg yolks VERY slowly and in turn, the egg mixture back into the lemon mixture rather slowly, or you could curdle the eggs and ruin your pie.  Also, do not get ANY egg yolks into the egg whites, or your meringue will not fluff (at all).  :-)  Otherwise...enjoy!!

text:
This pie was so amazing. :) I used a little more than 1/4 cup of lemon juice and the zest of one lemon to flavor the filling - as for the cooking, I stirred that pot until my hands were turning pink from the heat! ;D The filling was superb, tart and sweet (not boring or mellow in the least!), and I was so relieved by the simplicity of the recipe! ;D Definitely beyond my expectations!  Note: I was anticipating a very intimidating, impossible project (eggs scare me in recipes - what happens if the yolks scramble? What if the whites don't fluff up?), but it turned out to be oh-so-simple! :) For beginners like me (or, I was until I baked this pie ;D), don't be afraid! Just follow the instructions and everything will turn out A-OK! I will definitely make this again - my family raves about it all the time now.

text:
2011 Perfect recipe. I have made lemon meringue pie before and have always had problems. This recipe was the perfect balance between sour and sweet. I did substitute milk for water but that was the only change I made. I made this for Easter and took the last piece to my Grandma after our dinner because this is her favorite pie. 2012 Made this for Easter again - It's better to let the filling cool completely before making the meringue. Otherwise, you get a pool of sugary syrup and the two layers don't stick together. It was still very delicious! Also, I like to use 8 egg whites with 8 tbl of sugar so there is tons of meringue!

I followed the recipe as directed, but my results were less than desirable.  First, I thought the zest from TWO lemons gave the filling a bitter taste.  Secondly, the meringue looked perfect coming out of the oven, but as it was cooling I noticed that it was beggining to "weep".  Needless to say, that created a fluid layer between the meringue and the filling causing it not to adhere to it.  I may try making the pie again in the future with a some modification since Lemon Meringue Pie is my favorite pie, just not this one.

text:
Let me break it down a little:  For Flavor and Ease this pie gets 5 stars.  For overal consistency and directions it gets 4 stars.  Here are some valuable tips to perfection of this delicious pie!  You will need at least 5 tblsp of cornstarch as my pie was a little runny at less.  And, make sure to let your pie cool completely before making the meringue topping otherwise your merigue will being to melt underneath.  That's it!  Great tasting recipe and made a lemon meringue pie lover out of me.  Thanks for the recipe Grandma!!!

text:
This is a good recipe. I think it was my first time making lemon meringue pie from scratch and it was a lot easier than I thought. The flavour was nice but quite mild; not as tangy and lemony as my husband and I tend to like. I don't think it would make much of a difference, but I used 6 tbsp Realemon lemon juice instead of fresh squeezed and 1 tsp lemon extract instead of lemon zest (an approved substitution according to the allrecipes.com substitution list). I might try making this again, but I think I would try doubling the lemon extract next time to see if the flavour turns out more to my liking. Overall, a recipe worth trying.

Absolutely a WONDERFUL recipe.  I had RAVE reviews from my family. I followed the recipe exactly. Next time i MAY do the merigue prior to making the filling as I found myslef stirring the pot with my left hand and beating egg whites with my right. I was very fortunate to have gotten close to a half cup of juice from the lemons.  My Mom always used to place the lemons in a bowl filled with hot water prior to juicing them as it seemed to help the lemons produce more juice.  Don't know if that was an olde Irish folk tale, but, it sure seemd to work !! AWESOME recipe   :o)  Marilynne
Review:

userID:
2315036
Display Name:
cctaylor
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
30
favoritesCount:
726
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/215920.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Not sure what I did but the meringue never set up completely and I whipped it for 14 minutes! Since I didn't have enough meringue to seal the edges of the crust (SO important) it "de-flated" into the pie resulting in a gooey mess. I did use 1 1/4 c. white sugar, 3 1/2 TBSP. cornstarch, 1.5c milk vs. water, 1/2c. lemon juice and 1 TBSP. lemon zest, and added 1 tsp. vanilla extract. Let mixture boil ~1min, then stir in everything else and stir until thick ~1 min. For the meringue I whipped egg whites on high ~2min, added 1/2tsp. cream of tartar and 1/2tsp. vanilla, then sugar and whipped another 14 minutes. Let cool on counter ~1hr, then in fridge 3-6hrs uncovered, then cover.

This was a delicious pie even though I did not cook the lemon mixture for long enough.  The directions just say "until thick".  I think it needs to be cooked for over 10 minutes - until it gets really thick.  Take your time on cooking and I think it will turn out perfect!  I also heeded the advice of another reviewer to set the meringue on top of HOT lemon mixture and the meringue set really well.

text:
This was really good, like another user I used 1/2 cup of lemon juice (3 1/2 small lemons).  My husband loves lemon meringue pie so he was a little impatient, I let it cool for an hour on the counter and placed it in the fridge for 3 hours, when he cut into it the lemon part wasn't fully set yet, (still tasted good just a little runny).  By the next day it was set beautifully so I would suggest letting it sit longer than 3 hours in the fridge

Display Name:
mlbrindisi

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe has the perfect balance of tart to sweet. I like my lemon meringue pie to be a little more on the tart side, and this one got it just right! I made a few little adjustments to the recipe - I used milk instead of water, used 1 Tbsp lemon zest (from 2 lemons), used 1/2 cup lemon juice (from 3 lemons), whisked 1 tsp cream of tartar into the sugar for the meringue, and baked my pie longer than 10 minutes (closer to 15 minutes).  On my first try making this I baked it for 10 minutes like the recipe said, and it weeped and oozed liquid out from under the meringue (my first time making any lemon meringue pie). On my second try I baked it for closer to 15 minutes, and it came out perfect! No weeping at all, meringue clung nicely to the lemon filling, and the filling was just the right texture.

text:
The flavor and texture of the pie is excellent: the lemon was tangy and worked well as a refreshing summer pie, while the meringue was light and fluffy. I beat the egg whites, cream of tartar, sugar, and vanilla for 14 minutes. The meringue was perhaps too airy! But the greatest downfall of this pie was its runniness!  I even added extra cornstarch, but the pie was still runny and the meringue pulled away from the lemon custard. I don't know what went wrong!

text:
My mother in law requested I make this for mother's day. She asked what lemon filling I used...I told her "my own!" and she couldn't believe how perfect it tasted!   **a few tips**   Make sure you whip the wgg whites until soft peaks form (not just when they are foamy)...it takes longer if you put the sugar in too soon!  Also, I put the meringue on when the lemon curd was still hot, waited until the pie was completely cooled before I put it in the fridge....then took it out after 4 hours and it was weepy and the meringue pulled away from the sides. But the taste was amazing!

text:
my first ever lemon meringue pie and for the most part i think it turned out fairly good. i deducted 1 star for this recipe as there are no instructions for cooling. i used the zest from 1 lemon and the juice for 1.5 lemons topping up w/ bottled lemon juice to make up to 1/2cup. unlike a previous reviewer i could not take any for the rinds or zest texture in the pie. i did have some problems w/ a little bit of beading on top and moisture in the pie but that's prob my fault...i couldnt wait for the pie to completely cool b4 i had to try it! i will definitely try this recipe again!

I've watched/helped my mother and grandmother make lemon meringue pies since I was a little girl, but had never attempted it on my own. I couldn't reach either of them to get their recipes but craved a lemon meringue pie, so searched allrecipes for a good substitute for mom's pie. My husband and I are very pleased with this recipe and will definitely use it again.

text:
I made this for a friend's birthday party, as it is his favorite pie. I've never made a pie before, so I was a little wary of trying such a delicate pie as my first-even, but this recipe worked very well. I used just slightly more cornstarch (maybe 1/8 cup more). I baked for 15 minutes instead of 10, which sealed the pie nicely and beautifully browned the meringue. Allowed it to cool at room temperature for about 90 minutes and then refrigerated for several hours before serving.

text:
I decided to try this after all the great reviews, and it looked great and tasted great, but once I cut into it it fell apart.  So, I'm not sure what I need to do, but I made the filling the night before and didn't refrigerate the pie, also I'm not sure how long I let it thicken on the stove, but it was pretty thick when I put it in the pie shell.  So, I'd like to try it again,  maybe be sure to thicken it real well on the stove   and then make the meringue within an hour and then refrigerate.  The meringue was wonderful - I had the egg whites in the fridge and the beaters in the freezer before I started and added the crm of tarter and the vanilla.

text:
This recipe is AMAZING!  I have tried to find a good recipe for a long time and this one is definitely it!  Everyone raves about it when I make it.  I took the advice given and did 3 1/2 TBSP cornstarch and 2 oz lemon juice, 1 1/2 tsp lemon extract, and 1 tsp vanilla extract and it turned out great.  I also let is sit with the oven door open at least an hour after baking to cool and it set much better.

text:
I made this Pie for a family function and they were licking the plate clean.  One tip is not to put the meringue on the pie until it cools an hour or so on the countertop...  never put in the fridge as this increases the chance of weeping...  I find that Lemon Meringue Pie is wonderful the first day when it is fresh and the meringue is in top shape!

text:
I have never made a lemon meringue pie before, but my family had been asking for one for awhile so I thought I would give it a try.  I should have read many more reviews to find out how long to cook the filling, needs to boil for awhile. I didn't boil it long enough and turned out a bit to runny. And I was unsure about cooling instructions.  So I left it out for a hour or so before putting it in the fridge, and it weeped.  Wasn't sure what that was before I made it but had read it, and as soon as I saw it doing it I knew exactly what it was.  Not sure what to do different to make that not happen.  But my advice on the meringue, do add the cr of tarter and vanilla and then put in kitchen aid on high for 4 or so min.  Turned out GREAT.  My family loved it, even with the problems!

text:
Really great pie! My husband asked for a Lemon Meringue Pie for his birthday so I made this. We LOVE the tartness of this pie. I changed the meringue based on other reviews..Use superfine sugar, add 1/4 teaspoon of cream of tartar and 1/4 teaspoon vanilla.  Also, add 2 extra Tablespoons of sugar and mix until it is ALL dissolved. Feel it with your fingers to make sure it is dissolved. This will ensure your meringue will not fall.

I also prefer this to ensure the egg whites are done.

text:
This was my first lemon meringue pie, so I can't base my opinions on any other experience.  We felt that the zest from two lemons was way too much.  Perhaps zesting half of a lemon, but that's just our preference.  The texture was wonderful though!  Just the right tang in the lemon mixture.  I added 1/4th tsp cream of tartar to the meringue mixture as I have been taught that it makes better toppings.  The meringue was lovely.  Will make this again, I am sure.

text:
I have made this pie for every Thanksgiving, Christmas, Memorial Day, and Independence Day for the past 2 years now. My grandmother died recently and I never got the chance to get her "secret" recipes from her. I decided to try this one, and the title being "Grandmas Lemon Meringue Pie" was meant to be. After I made it and tasted it, I realized this is it!!! This tastes almost like my grandma's pie she made every year since I was a child. the family loves it, and I am actually making it tonight!!!!

Easy and delicious.  Add 1/2 teaspoon cream of tartar to the meringue to hold hold it together (lessen the drips) and cool for one hour before refrigerating for 4-6 hours before serving.  Wonderful!

Excellent recipe!

userID:
991136
Display Name:
RachelBC
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
30
favoritesCount:
147
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love lemon meringue, and have made it before, but using a pre-made crust, and one of those Sherriff's mixes for the lemon part.  This is the first time I've made the entire thing from scratch, and I was quite pleased with the results!

After reading the reviews, I decided to use storebought lemon juice, instead of juice from freshly squeezed lemons.  Based on the info from the reviews, I decided to try using an amount between 1/3 cup and 1/2 cup of lemon juice, and that seemed to be a nice balance of tartness and sweetness.

My lemon filling turned out nice and thick - no problems with runniness, like some other reviewers had. (I did make sure I cooked and stirred for quite a while)  I added 1 tsp cream of tartar to the meringue, as I usually do, and that turned out nicely, as well.

The *only* problem I had was that layer of water or juice between the lemon filling and the meringue.   It wasn't a major issue; I noticed it becaused I'd seen so many other reviewers mention it.  I didn't refrigerate the pie, but just left it on the counter after baking and served it fairly soon after that, so I'm not sure what the problem was.

Still, it's a very good pie recipe!  I think it's one that I'll be making again, since it's not very difficult and looks beautiful.
Review:

5

text:
Yummy, I love lemon pie and I love meringue, now everyone loves lemon meringue pie too!!! This pie is easy and good. I used 1/4 cup lemon juice and about 1 and 1/2 lemon zest; I taste it before adding the yolks to adjust the flavour. For the meringue, i use superfine sugar (berry sugar) and it looks great, I also add some vanilla powder. My meringue shrinks, thanks to a review I know what to do, but for some reason, it leaks something, then dries off, despite that, it looks great and tastes amazing. :D (if you have any suggestions as to why it leaks, please post, I use imperial baking margarine)

text:
This was my first attempt to ever make lemon meringue pie, and it turned out perfect, which really surprised me. I like that all of the ingredients are usually right here in my kitchen, so I can whip this up at the last minute, like when we have a craving for something lemony. It takes a bit of concentration to get the filling done, but even with my 3 year old assisting me we did fine. The result was absolutely delicious! Thank you!

text:
I found the filling to be wayyyy tooo Tart! So the next time I make it I will be cutting back on the lemons. Another problem I ran into was the fact that when you put the filling back on the stove after adding the egg yolks, it does not tell you how long to cook the filling before pouring it into the pie shell. It was thick but not thick enough, even after sitting in the refridgerator it was still a little runny. What is thick to one person might not be to another, there should be a temperature and time limit on cooking it before you pour it in the shell.But other than all that the filling did taste good,it was just too tart!

text:
This was a pain in the butt to make but soooo worth it.  I think what made it so hard was I didnt have a lemon zester and also I wasnt sure how thick to make the custard.  I didnt change anything except I added 1 tsp. of cream of tarter to the egg whites.  The pie turned out wonderful and everyone who tried it loved it.  I thought it tasted a little gritty but that may just be because I HATE cornstarch.  Overall it was a yummy pie.
